landingPage.title: Dev Dictionary
landingPage.description: The ultimate dictionary for developers. Find definitions for all the programming terms you need.

1.definition: A step-by-step procedure or formula for solving a problem. In programming, algorithms are used to perform calculations, data processing, and automated reasoning tasks.
1.example: Binary search algorithm to find an element in a sorted array

2.definition: Application Programming Interface: a set of rules and protocols that allows different software applications to communicate with each other.
2.example: REST API endpoints like GET /users or POST /orders

3.definition: A data structure that stores multiple elements of the same type in a sequential manner, accessible by index positions.

4.definition: A data type that can only have one of two values: true or false. Named after mathematician George Boole.
4.example: let isActive = true; let isComplete = false;

5.definition: An error, flaw, or fault in a computer program that causes it to produce incorrect or unexpected results.
5.example: Off-by-one error causing an array index out of bounds

6.definition: A blueprint or template for creating objects in object-oriented programming. It defines properties and methods that objects of that class will have.
6.example: class Car { constructor(brand, model) { this.brand = brand; this.model = model; } }

7.definition: A program that translates source code written in a high-level programming language into machine code or another programming language.
7.example: GCC compiler that converts C++ code to executable machine code

8.definition: Cascading Style Sheets: a stylesheet language used to describe the presentation and styling of HTML documents.

9.definition: An organized collection of information or structured data, typically stored electronically in a computer system and managed by a database management system (DBMS).

10.definition: The process of finding and fixing errors or faults in a computer program's code.
10.example: Using console.log() statements or breakpoints to trace program execution

11.definition: A reusable block of code that performs a specific task. Functions can accept input parameters and return output values.
11.example: function add(a, b) { return a + b; }

12.definition: A distributed version control system used to track changes in source code during software development.
12.example: git commit -m 'Add new feature' && git push origin main

13.definition: HyperText Markup Language: the standard markup language used to create web pages and web applications.

14.definition: Integrated Development Environment: a software application that provides comprehensive facilities for software development, including a code editor, debugger, and build automation tools.
14.example: Visual Studio Code, IntelliJ IDEA, Eclipse

15.definition: A high-level, interpreted programming language primarily used for web development to create interactive and dynamic web pages.

16.definition: JavaScript Object Notation: a lightweight, text-based data interchange format that is easy for humans to read and write.

17.definition: A programming construct that repeatedly executes a block of code while a specified condition is true.

18.definition: A data structure that contains data (properties) and code (methods). In object-oriented programming, objects are instances of classes.
18.example: let person = { name: 'Alice', age: 25, greet() { console.log('Hello!'); } }

19.definition: A JavaScript library for building user interfaces, particularly web applications. It uses a component-based architecture and virtual DOM.

20.definition: A programming technique where a function calls itself to solve a problem by breaking it down into smaller, similar subproblems.
20.example: function factorial(n) { return n <= 1 ? 1 : n * factorial(n - 1); }

21.definition: Structured Query Language: a programming language designed for managing and manipulating relational databases.
21.example: SELECT * FROM users WHERE age > 18 ORDER BY name;

22.definition: A data type used to represent text, consisting of a sequence of characters.

23.definition: A named storage location in computer memory that holds a value that can be changed during program execution.
23.example: let counter = 0; const PI = 3.14159; var message = 'Hello';

24.definition: A pre-written code structure that provides a foundation for developing software applications, offering reusable components and standardized ways to build and deploy applications.
24.example: React, Angular, Vue.js for frontend; Express.js, Django, Rails for backend
